One of four extant scenes from the Life of the Virgin, from an East Anglian altar frontal of c.1330-1340 (see Image 136). Mother and child at the extreme left are somewhat distanced from the elderly figure of St Joseph, wearing a distinctive Jewish hat and apparently fast asleep, leaning on his crutch. The Virgin is suckling her child at the breast. The Christ child is depicted more as a miniature adult figure than a baby. It is unusual for Mary, as here, to be depicted holding a bird, probably the gold-finch whose scarlet head-patch symbolizes Christ's passion, and is a prefiguration of death even at his nativity. (Compare the De Lisle Psalter, Image 216
